body_text:
#286 recommends we use an automated tool of some kind to monitor our dependencies and either keep them up to date, or at least alert us when they're out of date or have a security vulnerability.
After looking at their suggested tools, I think our best bet is:

Monitor Python dependencies with https://requires.io/. Have it send emails to a mailing list (normandy-notifications@mozilla.com?).

Monthly: Out-of-date notifications
Immediately: Insecure notifications


Run nsp regularly on our requirements.

Beyond alternatives to the above plan, the main open question is how to run nsp. Running it in CI won't ensure we get notified when a vulnerability is found until we make a PR or commit, but we don't have any regular jobs that just run and monitor the code.
@mozilla/normandy Thoughts?

title: Keep Python and JS requirements up to date / off insecure versions
body:
#286 recommends we use an automated tool of some kind to monitor our dependencies and either keep them up to date, or at least alert us when they're out of date or have a security vulnerability.

After looking at their suggested tools, I think our best bet is:

- Monitor Python dependencies with https://requires.io/. Have it send emails to a mailing list (normandy-notifications@mozilla.com?).
  - Monthly: Out-of-date notifications
  - Immediately: Insecure notifications
- Run [nsp](https://github.com/nodesecurity/nsp) regularly on our requirements.

Beyond alternatives to the above plan, the main open question is _how_ to run `nsp`. Running it in CI won't ensure we get notified when a vulnerability is found until we make a PR or commit, but we don't have any regular jobs that just run and monitor the code.

@mozilla/normandy Thoughts?
